First off I just want to say that ASW really knocked it out of the park with this port. Game looks fantastic and plays great online.

One thing that I'm amazed at is how awesome the training mode is for this game. They really teach you the VERY basics of how to go about playing this game. It's something that will ease beginning players in without having them feel overwhelmed by everything right from the get go. From there you've got a mode that teaches you combos and another mode that puts you in typical situations that you'll find yourself in from time to time while playing against opponents. Along with the is a very fleshed out freestyle training mode that they been offering us since 1998.

Online play seems pretty smooth right off the bat, although there are some who seem to be having issues with lobbies at the moment. Aside from that, playing in game is smooth. If there was lag then I'm oblivious to it. The few matches that I had so far felt great... Aside from me getting stomped into oblivion.

While some people will scoff at the number of characters in this game, I see nothing wrong with it as you can see ASW seems to have gone with quality before quantity. Every character has been animated in a way to replicate the animation frames from the older games. It's a joy just to sit back and just watch the characters, attacks, specials, instant kills, and intros/outros.

I haven't had the chance to try out Story, Arcade, or any other of the modes so far due to trying to learn Ramlethal at the moment, But as soon as I do, I'll make sure to update this review.  But from what I've experienced you shouldn't even hesitate at spending your hard earned money on this. It even comes with a slew of goodies. Including an awesome soundtrack.

reviewText:
Overall, a great game with some PC specific issues & buggy multiplayer
I never thought I'd see the day these games landed on PC.

By no means am I a fighting game pro, in fact I probably suck at them compared to the average enthusiast. But I am very fond of them nonetheless, and have been playing fan favourites since childhood with GG and KoF being my favourite franchise due to the cast of characters. When I saw Xrd had hit steam, I immediately purchased it, and boy, do I have no ragrets.

General Gameplay

As far as fighting games go, I'd rate GG as one friendlier to newcomers to the genre than other mainstream favourites like street fighter, some difficulty levels above the level of Tekken. Most competent gamers should be able to maintain themselves throughout the singleplayer modes of the game and the skill ceiling is high enough to maintain a healthy skill diversity between players whilst retaining the accessibility of the game to an audience simply playing for fun. Don't treat my opinion like it's worth a damn though, I really can't git gud at these games even after a decade of playing them.

GG Xrd comes with plenty of content as far as gameplay modes go, with a classic arcade mode, an item based progression mode called M.O.M and a story mode to boot following the arcade completion. Multiplayer is also an option with network play available to players that decide to get their ♥♥♥ handed to them online.

Learning the game itself is very friendly to new players and perhaps the most newcomer-welcome title I've ever laid my hands on as far as fighting games go, with an extremely helpful tutorial mode, and challenge modes for each character that lay out all the potential skills and combinations that one can master as a beginner. Though I'd rather have input commands displayed in a clearer manner, they are indeed shown for those who wish to monitor where their buttons are being pressed.

A common complaint of Xrd is the lack of characters and lack of some fan favourites from the cast of previosu games, even with the free DLC. This is personally a more important detractor to those who have enjoyed previous titles, since as far as the game itself goes there is barely enough variety to just about keep the matchups entertaining. More irritating however, is the EU implementation of GG Xrd (this release) which lacks a lot of the DLC characters released in Japan.

Finally, the most important factor of gameplay in fighting games; controls. They're tight, very responsive, extremely customisable (keyboard gamers rejoice!) and displayed clearly for beginners. No complaints in this department.

Graphics (They're beautiful)

Xrd is interesting in the sense that the game meets a halfway between old school 2d sprites and new-generation 3D models that older players tend to dislike. Arc have somehow managed to develop fully 3D characters in the unreal engine, whilst making them appear in a 2D anime style during play. This is supplemented by GORGEOUS animation for intros, cutscenes, special moves and finishing moves for each character. There are few complaints from me as far as graphics go, and though some players dislike this graphics style, I personally am extremely fond of this hybrid approach and pray that more JP fighting games take this technique to develop it further.

Audio

If you're a fan of JRock or Guitar instrumentals in general, you will be in love with this soundtrack. Even from the perspective of an exclusively rap listener, it is undeniable that a lot of love was put into the soundtrack (and the game in general).

But far more impressive than the soundtrack is the voice acting. With anime industry veterans taking the cast for each character, dubbing over everything, everything from menu voices to every cutscene and finisher. Though it's become somewhat standard to expect great voice acting from fighting games, it still blows me away that Xrd has the VA/Seiyuu cast that it does.

PC Port

If there's one thing JP devs suck at unanimously, it's usually the PC port. As far as Xrd goes, users have been cropping up with performance issues here and there, usually in an intermitted manner. Anecdotal experiences will vary and I personally take them with a hint of salt, but it appears that the game is not completely perfect and those with lower spec systems should take heed of this. Fortunately, steam now gives us refunds so it's easy enough to test this out and see how it runs. I should also note that finishers/cutscenes are locked to 30FPS (correct me if I am mistaken, please) if you care about that.

More importantly however, is the network play implementation. Many players have been complaining of buggy and malfunctioning network play, and though the connection issues aren't as frequent for me when I try it on the few occassions that I did, I would again, take heed of this and check pcgamingwiki or google for potential issues that may arise from this port. All in all, though the port is evidently far from perfect, the disappointing standard set for PC ports by Japanese game studios has been demolished by Xrd's PC implementation. Please, just check that the game will work for you first, and make sure to do this within the refund window.

Finally, there are some issues with the UI being upscaled to ludicrous degrees on the PC port, leading to quite a lot of overlap/interception between elements of the HUD. It's a minor annoyance but a consistent annoyance nonetheless.

Final Notes

There's really not much left to say, this is one of my shorter reviews and is also a review for a genre of video games that I have very little expertise in. I would take what I say with a grain of salt, but if you are a newcomer to the genre, know that other scrubs like yourself are having a lot of fun with this beautiful game and recommend you purchase it, especially if it's on sale like it is at the time of this review. As far as fighting games go, the volume of content that you get with a learning curve that won't immediately throw you off from playing the game more are more than enough reasons to at least try a few hours before refunding it.

reviewText:
10/10 would Dragon Install and Ground Viper into Eddie Drill and get insta-killed by a Zato main again.

Talking seriously now, there's a lot about this game and it's intricacies that I simply do not know how to put down into a small, digestable review that someone like yourself might scroll down the store page and read to see if you want to buy it.

I'll start with myself I suppose. Before I bought this game I had little to no experience in fighting games other than the original Super Smash Bros. and Brawl. I've heard of the Fighting Game Community and Street Fighter peaked my interest a few times but it never really hooked me into it.

So exactly why did I decide to buy Xrd? A fighting game that really shouldn't be recommended for newcomers? Because of the MOTHER! ♥♥♥♥ING! SOUNDTRACK!!! The OST in this game is absolutely amazing for any rock and even metal lover. Guitar riffs are almost always original and most songs feel like they could be seperate video game themes simply from how good they sound. Diva of Destruction, Give Me A Break, Starry Story, Just Do It are all particular songs that I just can't listen to enough.

But what of the rest of the game?
Well the designs and functionality of each character is extremely unique even within the game's universe. One character does not feel like the other and usually has their own unique playstyle. You have the Big Brooding Badass Sol Badguy who uses a sword more like a hammer and can bust out his Dragon form when ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan and then you have the (21 year-old) Japanesse Loli Pirate May who is basically the equivalent to Anime Aquaman in terms of power but is actually impactful to the story and is quite useful. From a design standpoint you have a crap ton of variety of characters so you're almost gaurenteed to find someone you like.

The gameplay itself is as solid as I've ever seen. Almost anything can be answered with anything else. The mechanics of Roman Cancel, Faultless Guard, Jump Cancel, Burst and much more intricate mechanics make sure that literally no match is decided by character selection it's all skill and the community as far as I've seen backing this game will do everything in their power to make sure you git gud.

Would I recommend this to someone interested in the fighting genre? Yes. Absolutely yes. Even if you don't take the game seriously enough to be competetive the characters and art style of the game is unique of itself and deserves to at least be tried. I believe anyone who's in the FGC and hasn't at least played a few matches of this game is sorely missing out.

Would I reommend this to just any casual video game player though? No. As I said before there is a lot of stuff to take in when you first pick up this game and it can easily get overwhelming. I studied this game and it's mechanics months before it came out on Steam and the tutorial still overwhelmed me because of how much I needed to consider in a match. It's ultimately fair but at the same time it can be grueling and even cruel at times to newbies.

If you're thinking of buying this game though then go for it. You won't be disappointed I promise. The soundtrack is amazing, characters are great, artstyle and graphics mesh really well together with the combat and ultimately this all comes together to make both the game itself and it's individual battles between players fun to watch and fun to play.

Currently, I'm waiting for SFV to be released so I can get into another fighting game and then after that I'm going to be waiting for BlazBlue ChornoPhantasm Extend (another game I've been hyping myself up to since it's from the same developers that makes GGXrd.) I can wholeheartedly say that this game is the game that got me into the Fighting Games Community and for that I couldn't thank GGXrd, Daisuke Ishiwatari and Arcsys enough.

A word of advice to the newbies from a fellow newbie though. YOU WILL GET YOUR ♥♥♥ KICKED IN! But do not fret. In fact embrace the ♥♥♥ kicking. Learn from the ♥♥♥ kicking. The only way you're going to ultimately get better is to find a character you like with a playstyle to match your mindset and then just go online and fight. At first you might be discouraged but do not quit. You ARE getting better and you will eventually see your struggle come to fruition when you land your first dust-to-knock down combo in a match, then when you land a perfect Roman Cancel and then finally you'll score your first few wins. And the best part about all that is that you know you did it yourself with no handholding.

Well that was a much longer review than I'd hope.

Somewhat of an early review, but here we go. I've been looking forward to this port for awhile.

PROS-
-Stylish look. Keeps the anime artstyle that made the series true, but also uses 3D models. It's actually insane how crazy good these models look and how they apparently aren't 2d sprites.
-Fairly similar to other Guilty gear titles. It's slightly slower in terms of speed and it's not as technical, but these mechnical charges are extremely small.
-This is a port, and the port (for the most part) is great.
- Netcode is FAN-♥♥♥♥ING-TASTIC. It's seriously real good. I played over 40 matches today and none of them had noticable lag. Of course, I'm sure this could change with distance between players, but this is definitely one of the best PC fighting games in terms of its netcode.
- Challenging difficulty that makes the game rewarding to learn. Not incredibly easy to pick up and definitely hard to master.
-Pretty decent sized roster
-The rock and metal themes in this game are iconic and amazing to fight to. Makes fights even more entertaining

Cons-
-The only real issue I have with this port is a possible memory leak issue. Many people have reported issues with fps slowly dropping over time when playing the game. It seems to be related to dxinput controllers. I simply unplugged my fightstick while playing the game, and plugged it back in and got a stable 60 fps again. But this is still an unacceptable issue for a game that shouldn't be very demanding.
-The level of entry in this game is very steep. If you never played a fighting game, this one isn't bad to start with, but you'll be losing a lot (as you would with most fighting games anyway if you're a noob).
-The story is odd and non-traditional. It can be a bit offputting to others.
- No real options to go past 1080p from what I've read. Could be wrong.
- This version will be outdated soon, as GGxrd Revelator is coming out soon. I'm glad Arcsys Jp decided to finally get a company to port this game for us, but if they really want these games to do well, they need to make sure to keep them updated at a timely fashion just like with the console versions.
- Online is not cross play with ps4/ps3. Steam users only, which will eventually twindle, since fighting games aren't big on PC.

Overall, I think this is a great game. Amazing fighting game and I'm having fun learning it. I hope Revelator comes out on pc around the same time as the console versions. However, there are some port issues that hopefully get ironed out by the next patch for the game. Regardless, I still recommend this game, but please be wary of your purchase, since you might run into some issues due to shoddy porting. My experiences had a quickfix, but who knows what you'll run into.

8/10.

The game is fast paced - you need to keep your pants up at all times, actively guard the incoming swings and watch for unguardable stuff with a counter at the ready.
The game is mechanically robust - which is a synonim for complicated. The closest genre to fighting games is RTS, so think of it as a starcraft 2 of fighting games. There are about 20 different systems you can game in there, some available to all, some unique to certain characters. For example, to guard against a normal strike, you have a choice of 4 different types of guard (normal guard, instant guard, faultless defense and blitz shield), all have different properties and execution difficulty (think RTS micro) - they can pull the enemy closer, push them away, and even open for a counter; and not only you have to guard yourself, but watch the enemy guard, as even getting pounded on your guard can be turned into an advantage when the attacker is not paying attention and lets his pants drop.
The game is not constrained - anything you do can be meaningful, and in any situation there's something you can do. You can break the enemy's combos, you can turn around a match with a nickel of health. The same applies to your opponent, so watch out to not be baited for a combo-breaker by a prepared opponent.
The game is not hard to learn - the combo system has very minimal rules and feels light; generally speaking, every move has a set duration of stun it applies, and every move fast enough to hit during that window is a combo, applying its own stun. reviewText:
-Intro:
I am just going to get it out of the way; Guilty Gear is the king of airdashers, or anime fighters. The first Guilty Gear on the PS1 is the one that started the madness of jump blocking, clashing, dashing through the air, and instantly killing the opponent in a fun anime fashion. I got into the series recently after watching the Guilty Gear XRD Top 8 at Evo. There were many amazing moments, and some shameful upsets, (I am looking at you, Woshige), so I was instantly hooked. I had the delight of starting from the beginning with an emulator and experiencing the series' growth. I worked my way up through Guilty Gear X, XX, Accent Core, and now we are here, (I am sorry that I didn't play you, Overture).

-Graphics:
Guilty Gear XRD is the revival of the series after ages of experimenting and releasing revisions of XX, and boy, it delivers. How much? Enough for it to be my favorite fighting game of all time. Enthusiasts say that fighting games are all about gameplay, but I cannot ignore what this game does with its graphics even in my horrid CRT monitor and bad system specs. The game looks like a drawn anime, but the catch is that it's actually rendered in full 3D with cel-shading that makes it look like an anime. You can see glimpses of this everytime you perform Dust attacks (Which are basically full-screen launchers), when you perform Overdrives, when the round is over, and with Instant Kills. The Instant Kills are pretty hard to hit, so they aren't broken; they are pretty damn rewarding tho, and I always compared them to Mortal Kombat fatalities as they get easier to use when the enemy is about to lose the match. Everything in this game is gorgeous and full of personality, however, the framerate on model animations is pretty jaggy, (Apparently because they wanted to make it similar to the animation of anime).

During the following paragraphs I will go over all the new mechanics that the game has, so if you are not interested in reading that technobabble you can skip to the content section:

-Mechanics:
XRD revamps the Roman Cancel system, as XX's was kinda unreliable with its forced roman cancels. RC's cancel attacks and slow down time significantly, giving you time to use them effectively. Now Roman Cancels are divided into three versions, Red, Yellow, and Purple. Red RC's are used when linked after an attack that hits the opponent and can extend combos, but they cost half of your Tension bar (The bar used for Overdrives), they are often better than overdrives because they are already hit confirmed and are usually friendlier for hit scaling. Yellow RC's are used after an attack that doesn't hit the opponent yet or at all; they cost 25% of the bar, so you can use them often to cancel out of punishable moves and slow down time like a vampire. You don't want to use Purple RC's, as they are just like the Yellow ones but cost 50% bar, they happen when you are late to do a YRC. There are many other new mechanics, like the Blitz Shield, which is a parry that leaves the opponent open to combos (It costs 25% of the gauge, but you usually get 12.5% back from the combo, so it's very good), and the R.I.S.C. Gauge, which punishes overly defensive play with forced counter attacks and stun.

The best thing about this game is that there isn't just multiple variables to everything, such as the above uses of RC's, the two uses for the Burst attack (One to get out of combos and the other to attack and get a full bar of tension), and the R.I.S.C gauge decreasing with hits as a secondary hit scaling, but additionally, there is an answer for everything as well, such as Bursts being thrown, Blitz Shield follow-ups being Blitz Shielded back, and the usual Block>Attack>Throw>Block. What Arc Sys has made a system deep as an ocean, but it isn't inaccessibly complex, everything that I just told you is in the in-depth tutorial which explains every single system of the game. Anything that isn't said in the tutorial, such as Jump Installs and Faultless Defense Cancels, are explained in character Challenges for those who have them. It may sound like a lot to keep in mind, but you can always revisit the tutorial, learn combos in the Challenge mode, and practice the systems and matchups in Mission Mode.

-Content:
I mentioned the Tutorial, Challenge mode, Mission mode, but there is also a Training mode; all of these are part of the Practice section and there is 600 challenges and 50 missions, more than enough to provide a great learning experience. Additionally, there is a singleplayer Arcade mode, which has cutscenes for each character (Except the three bonus characters and the arcade boss). These cutscenes serve as a prologue to the game's Story mode, a 5 hour long anime Movie"

reviewText:
Guilty Gear Xrd is the most beautiful 2D fighting game utitlizing 3D graphics I've ever seen. Nothing can even compare to it. Street Fighter? Mortal Kombat? They can't even compare to the vibrant style of Guilty Gear. Much like how Guilty Gear X was a huge graphical achivement for 2D fighters back in 2000, Guilty Gear Xrd has set a new achivement for next gen fighting games.

Once you get past how mind blowing this game looks and get into the gameplay, it's very familiar. This game very much feels alot like classic Guilty Gear, they did a great job keeping the feel of the game very much the same. Utlizing Roman Cancels has been eased a great deal and are easier than ever to use, although some people may not apperciate the changes, particularly the slowdown during them, as well as how simple and even derp they can be this time around. I wasn't a fan of FRC's in the older Guilty Gear XX games, I felt they were just too hard to use and the new Roman Cancel system is alot easier to use, but maybe a bit too easy. It's not hard to really abuse this system and it can be quite obnoxious. It's hard to please both crowds though. Really the only new mechanic that I think really raises an eyebrow is Danger Time, which is just really silly and shouldn't of been in the game.

You can't discuss Guilty Gear without mentioning the audio. Most of the classic Guilty Gear sound effects are back, and the cast of characters sound great (In Japanese). I'm still not really used to most of the new character themes in the game yet, I liked alot of the original Guilty Gear X/XX soundtrack, but given time it'll probably grow on me.

Online Play can be either hit or miss as with most fighting games, but it's a good system allowing several games in one lobby to go on at the same time.

I'm looking forward to watching Xrd grow and bring back many classic Guilty Gear characters over the next few years.

Conclusion: Arc System Works is starting to become one of my favorite game developers. Now that they publish their own games on PC we are getting high quality releases with full content at reasonable prices while the game is still relevant. I'm hoping they look to further break the trend of price gouging on fighters by releasing the next installment, -Revalator-, for a discounted price for owners of GGXrd -Sign-.

reviewText:
I'd like to preface this review by stating that I'm not a fighting game enthusiast.

In fact, the only real experience I have with 2D Fighters prior to GGXrd is The King of Fighters XIII-- and I wasn't really a fan of that game. Despite my inexperience with the genre, I can say that Guilty Gear Xrd -SIGN- has salvaged my interest.

CHARACTERS:

The characters in Guilty Gear are, well, ridiculous. From a sleeping boy who wields a weaponized bed to a British time traveler, the cast covers all the bases. Each fighter has a unique playstyle and, in many cases, a more peculiar fashion sense. Whether you want to fight with swords, sickles, anchors, flowers, billiard balls, or your own hair, Guilty Gear has it all. Another nice aesthetic are the palette options (skins) for each character-- all of them look great!

GAMEPLAY:

Although my arcade-fighter backlog isn't extensive by any means, I know that GGXrd plays great. The controls are simple, combos easy to pick up, and the fighting overall feels tight and responsive. Fights against NPCs seem fair with an appropriate amount of challenge. This means I can actually play Arcade and other AI game modes without the fights becoming too tedious or underwhelming.

SOUND/VISUAL:

Something that anyone, novice or veteran to fighting games, will notice immediately is the polish  all over  GGXrd. While the character models are 3D rendered, they still manage to appear beautifully 2D. This effect really brings the game to life and allows for over-the-top battle intros and special attack cinematics.

The voice acting in this game is impressive, too. Having no original preference, I tried out both the English and Japanese vocals and ended up loving both. Each character's tone seems to fit so well, their voices emotive and packed with energy.

Xrd's soundtrack is also worth mentioning. From what I can tell, a lot of the BGMs were brought back from past Guilty Gear titles and given new life-- my personal favorite being May's  Starry Story .

OVERALL (TL;DR)

reviewText:
Guilty Gear Xrd is essentially a huge step up from other 2D fighters that were ported to the PC. It has little to no bugs especially with arcsys working hard to fix the game often. For a game not originally made with a PC port it's got pretty good online play albeit it still needs improvements.

Pros:
To start off with what GGXrd does right is that for a game that was originally for PS3/PS4, it runs just as, if not even better on PC. No real input delay, and is even supported by a diverse amount of controllers (keyboard included). Although it should be noted that the controller needs to be plugged in before you start the game otherwise the game will only recognize the keyboard inputs.
Graphicswise it looks and performs better than the PS3/PS4 version (as long as you have a graphics card better than the standard Intel card). However, the game can still even run around 50-60 fps on the Intel graphics if you turn down the settings. Don't expect it to look pretty though. The game itself runs on Unreal Engine 3 which was originally intended for Windows.
Also, the online lobby system is one of the best I've seen. It has 8 player lobbies, with 4 battle rooms for those players to interact. So it doesn't just come down to 8 players with 2 fighting while 6 spectate. You have full control of your player icon to move around the rooms and switch what battle room you want to participate in. Whether you want to play winner next in line or just spectate. There's even an AFK section for players who haven't pressed a button in awhile so people don't get stuck on empty battle rooms.

The character cast itself is really well done for a fighting game. Very diverse and stylish character designs. And the characters themselves offer playstyles suited for almost everyone. Starting from simple straightforward characters like Sol Badguy and Ky Kiske, to zoners like Axl, and for the people who like playing two characters at once there's Zato-1.

Cons:
This is not really a problem I've come across with the PS3/PS4 version. However, it's worth mentioning because people are bound to come across this issue. Like I mentioned previously, the online play itself works fine. Connecting into player lobbies is mostly consistent especially if you're playing with someone in the same region. Playing with someone far away can cause input delay, which can even reach to 10-14 frame delay which is almost unplayable. In my experience, I've tried playing with people on the other side of the world and sometimes had 4 ms delay so it can work sometimes far away. The biggest problem with GGXrd on the PC port is that there's problems connecting to people, especially with ranked mode. And also if you're playing on strict NAT you won't be able to connect to people at all. Which can be a problem for colleges specifically as most run on strict NAT.

Overall rating - 7.5/10
It's a great fighting game, and a must buy for arcsys fans especially if you're a Blazblue player. Would rate higher if not for it's issues with the online function that I touched upon. Although, arcsys has been dishing out patches continuously to better improve the online as well as other bugs.

It's the same great game as it is on consoles, with better graphics in-game, and some welcome changes for a PC port. The lack of in-depth options is dissapointing, and the game has quite a few minor issues that hurt this port. That being said, this port has fantastic netcode! I had 2F delay to somebody in Seattle! It's not rollback, but it's pretty damn good. I recommend this game to anybody interested in fighting games (so long as you don't gush over Elphelt :^) )

I'll now list the issues I've discovered.

You can not change your resolution in full screen mode. Full screen is a seperate resolution option.
The games UI is from the PS3 port. The in game graphics are not, and neither is the hud. Unfortunately, this makes the menus look awful when upscaled to 1080p. They don't look very good at 720p either.
Anti-aliasing seems to have no effect. I can clearly see jaggy lines no matter which option I set my AA to.
There are no (obviously) usable configs within the games files. I can not change the settings to optimize it's performance on my system. (This is somewhat alleviated now thanks to a community guide showing me how to downsample from 4K resolution. Game looks pretty great and runs well.)
The game seems to be having memory issues for me. If I play the game for quite a while, the framerate will slow down between 30-50 and run extremely poorly.

The game will claim they declined the match almost instantly, but this happens with all players in ranked mode right now.

This issues aren't the end of the world, but I'm sure we'd all appreciate it if these problems were fixed.

Also, Elphelt should be removed from the game. Not really, but she just doesn't fit in with the cast if you ask me. Who won a competition to get their waifu OC in the game?

reviewText:
Note : This review is post the 3.2 GB patch for the game

First lets talk about the graphics in this game, they are 3D with an anime style similar to the popular series Abunai sisters, but the design in Guilty Gear Xrd puts their own twist on this by making it not a pile of ♥♥♥♥ to look at, I love the look of this game and I can't help but when a KO in this game happens but put a screen shot of the lovely camera angles that show.

I heard that the only reason that they changed the graphics to 3d was to have a alway availible goto model now to save on the budget on sprite development and never have to worry about them showing age for a long time, but if them making great looking anime styled models with lovely backgrounds is them trying to save the budget I want to see what they can do when they're spending it all.

Makes me wish there was a mod to move the camera in battle behind you, I wouldn't even care how much harder it would make the game I just want to see it and take more screen shots of this gorgeous game.

In my opionion the game is really fun, cast is very varied in what every character is capible of and what they use to get the job done and it can also be said that fighting no 2 players is the same since everyone seems to find something else great about the character to use, just when you think you've got that characters play style down.

From the Roman canceling, rejects, faultless blocking and even more it seems like there is way to much content to get used to at the start but online there are always beginner servers to get a hand in with playing others who are not yet themselves that good at the game.

For a first fighter this could seem a bit like too much but it's really not a bad choise because it means if you're into learning a game inside and out it would be a like being a kid in a candy shop

Now to get to some of the negitives of this game.

The story mode really is just talking the whole time with not a ounce of game play in it and the animation for such lovely 3d modles doesn't due much justice, it's like seeing static VN portraits in 3D and this really shows as an issue when you see fights in story mode look like they're played through micro soft power point.

Next is the online in this game, it's functional if that is a thing to call it but you'll constantly be kicked from rooms that claim good connection and then somehow get into that 0 connection room you clicked by mistake, also the online matches after the patch in this game have lead to a few times the game just crashes.

The patch claims to have fixed the ranked mode in this game but it turned into the same click their name until the game gives up and lets you play that it was before, combined that with the crashing now online and I don't even want to play ranked from fear of being called a rage quitter.

Then we get to the main issue that I've have had with the game and how well it runs, going by having task manager in the side while running the game to check on it I seen that the specs post patch from pre patch are a good 150% higher and it didn't fix the issue where as the game is running the specs of the game slowly but constantly go up leading to eventual lag on the menu of all things, but here just opening and closing the game seems to reset it.

this is something I really want arksys to get into fixing because the game seems like otherwise it would be able to run really well on much weaker machines.

It may look like I dragged way much longer on the negitives then the possitives here but when you get past the problems that come mainly in the online and the story mode of the game what you will find is a great fighting game that if you are a fan of the genre you will not want to miss by miles.

Over all the possitives of having a great and closer to the current version of the game come out on PC overlap the negitives but in the future I hope they at least figure how tofix the current online.

I was pretty suprised but also almost scared when ArcSys announced that they would bring an actually current title to PC,  since up until now they just brought somewhat dated titles with ports of varying quality to steam.

With GUILTY GEAR Xrd -SIGN- we have a topnotch Anime-Fighter just dripping with style. The characters and stages just look absolutely stunning and are beatifully designed and go along well with the astounding Butt-Rock soundtrack.

While Blazblue usually goes for a story mode for each character with multiple endings, Xrd features the sort of arcade mode you have come to expect from most fighting games and an actual watch/readable story of approximately 3 hours length.
There also is the so called M.O.M. mode where you have charcater progression with leveling and items and fight enemies with special stat-modifiers that includes items that you can actually use in combats, such as bombs and potions.

reviewText:
Let me tell you something: If you're a fan of fighting games, you HAVE to play this game.
If you played previous games before, you notice some changes in Xrd. First, Multi pathed story mode is removed (from what I've seen so far) and for a better understanding of the story, you have to complete arcade mode with all of the characters first and then move on to the story mode. Second, Unlike the previous games (or BlazBlue series), Xrd has 2.5D visuals. Third, Because of changes in story mode system, arcade mode is changed too and you don't have to face Ramlethal (A.K.A. The boss character) for every character. I mean, with some characters (like Slayer), you never get to fight her.
Now for the story... From what I read, the story begins after the events of Guilty Gear 2: Overture (which I never played :( ) and tells the events of.... Well, I better not spoil it here. Also, Xrd has very great surprises for you if you have played GGXXAC+R on Steam. like:  Chipp is now a president!  and you can unlock several musics from AC+R for matches. (like The Midnight Carnival)
Gameplay is still the same: Fast and hard to master. And everything is still in place: Instant kills, Roman cancels, Dust move, Burst, etc...

Overall, It's a very great game and this port had a way better launch on PC than Lag Kombat X. Sure, It has some problems (that I know will be fixed) but it's playable. Also, some of those problems are fixed now (like the ugly looking HUD) after the 3GB update (large size, don't you agree?).
Okay, let's finish this. You want to have a very good fighting game? Then buy this game AND GET READY TO ROCK!
Oh, and by the way.... Thank you Arc System Works for bringing this great fighting game to PC platform. I'm looking forward to see BBCPE and Xrd Revelator!

Absolutely amazing game.  Very polished in all aspects.  The graphics are simply stunning.  Netcode seems very good too, I'm living in Taiwan and playing with my friend back in Hawaii (my connection seems to go to california, and then bounces back to him in Hawaii so that should speak loads for the netcode quality) without any instability, just a few frames of delay, which is all auto calucated for seamless play.

I'm just average skill level at fighting games so I can't give any detailed pro's and cons on mechanics but it feels very fair, but also high skill cap.  It doesn't seem like any mechanics have been removed since I last played GG X2.

I don't have a single complaint for this game, and I'm usually a heavy critic.  The only possible complaint anyone could have is that you can't use the mouse for menu navigation, it all has to be done via controller or WASD/arrows. reviewText:
Let me level with you. Guilty Gear is an amazing game, arcsys makes the best 2D air dashing fighting games in the world. XRD is a fresh reboot, which throws out a lot of the complexity from the older games while maintaining the classic feel of some of the most iconic characters around.

The systems are great with some draw-backs here and there, and the visual style of xrd is second to none.

XRD is a game that plays fast and aggressive while looking amazing.

However the PC port is extremely garbage. If you look around Dustloop, SRK, and the steam community you'll find lots of complains about frame rate issues.

I've got an amd cpu and an nvidia gpu, my friend has the same gpu and one model worse on the amd cpu. His game runs fine, mine doesn't.

Now, what happens is after a number of matches (about 10 or so) the framerate goes from a solid stable 60, down to 30 and the game becomes unplayable.

As I've mentioned, I looked into this a lot before refunding the game, this happens to all combinations of amd and intel cpus and also nvidia and amd gpus. Online, offline, it doesn't matter. For many people the game is just unplayable.

XRD is a fantastic game and I've loved it since the NA release on ps3, I'm just upset that I can't play with my pc friends.

For the sake of clarity I've tried a couple of fixes that were suggested online, both on forums and the steam community. I tried various configurations with nvidia control panel, in game settings, resets, game cache validation, re-installing the game, and nothing fixed the problem. Time and time again, after a number of matches the frame rate would halve rendering the game unplayable.

One of the best fighting game series to have ever existed.

Guilty Gear Xrd is one of the most beautiful out of the series, Arc Sys went beyond and was able to create stunning art that despite it's 2D looks is rendered in 3D, not only that but they upped the ante on their character designs overhauling the designs of old favorites like Sol (Especially that Dragon Install) and Ky, and made new additions to the roster such as the Valentines. Landing that overdrive, that DESTROY, chaining up attacks, everything about this game will make you feel good and feel cool about every move you do. You can easily learn the controls to this game, but boy if you think you can face off against people in Guilty Gear like it was Skullgirls, you best be calling GG because there's a long way to mastering this fighting game series and that's what makes this game have lasting replayability. There's always something new to learn at every turn at every character.

And if that's not enough for you, THE MUSIC IS GUARENTEED TO PUMP YOU THE ♥♥♥♥ UP, Daisuke Ishiwatari has the best music for fighting games ESPEICALLY FOR GUILTY GEAR. His music is full of heavy rock with inspiration from Gun and Roses and other bands (Even the game itself has inspiration and references to Rock music) Everything about the music fits the fast and crazy fights of Guilty Gear, that to be honest without it Guilty Gear wouldn't feel like Guilty Gear.

Overall this game is a solid 10/10, 11/10, ROCK YOU/10 because it's hard as ♥♥♥♥ to hate this game, moreso this amazing port to the PC.

This quick review is from the perspective of a PC gamer.
I've always been a fan of fighting games in general as I grew up with arcade machines around me but I didn't quite find the game that was simple enough to get me in and enjoy it from the start, but at the same time deep enough so I can put some effort in a particular character and not having to switch to another one in case of bad matchups.
This game totally delivers that and much more.
The presentation is mind-blowing, over the top animations, great music that fits perfectly with the action, plenty of content such as arcade mode, versus mode (online or local) with replays so you can learn from it, story mode for those who want to learn more about the characters' background which is basically a long anime (with no gameplay), M.O.M. mode that adds an RPG feel to the game with progression per character (I heard you'll need 20+ hours to finish one) with customization with new skills that work with a cooldown system, tons of unlockables through in-game money you earn by just playing the game.
So, if you're looking for a very solid, complete fighting game, though very demanding if you're into competitve online (which, by the way, I heard has a great netcode that feels almost like local multiplayer),  still totally enjoyable for single player or local multiplayer with friends on the couch, I'd say run for it, by far the best fighting game I've seen on PC.
Great job and thank you Arc System Works for this amazing port.

reviewText:
After literally more than a decade of EIGHT versions of X & X2 (not including the awkward spin-offs) Guilty Gear finally gets the proper sequel it deserves. Rebuilt to be an entirely new entry it has the same excellent fast gameplay as X2 with newbie friendly tweaks, five new characters, and the absolute best visuals of any 3D anime game to date. Between the game's approach to story and M.O.M (survival with persistant RPG stats) mode, it also has the most worthwhile singleplayer content in the entire series. It thankfully even has a tutorial mode extremely similar to BlazBlue's.

The most unavoidable weakness of the game is the missing characters, but that's only a minor complaint considering how surprisingly good the roster is without Dizzy, Baiken, Johnny, Robo-Ky, etc. All the returning characters have been intelligently picked for diversity's sake and all the new characters are worthy additions that bring something fresh to the franchise, Ramlethal and Leo in particular are excellent.

The other thing that needs to be mentioned is the legitimately terrible english voice acting, which can be switched back to familiar Japanese voices thankfully. (I only mention this because it's on by default. If you're already familiar with the Guilty Gear series you will want to switch it immediately. Ky sounds ♥♥♥♥ing awful.)

Most concerning however is the online mode. While it defintely works with friends with very little issues I've had serious problems finding games with the search function, I've especially never found a ranked match. Weirdly enough I've set up public player rooms and they eventually become populated and work fine. I'm not sure what that's about but it needs to be patched.

This is Ark System Work's most polished game to date, and I cannot wait to see Xrd grow stronger. Just make sure your computer will be able to run the game at a stable 60fps for no slowdown, and then ideally with a controller prepare yourself for one of the best fighting games ever made.

reviewText:
Upon intensive testing after the recent patch, somehow things improvise drastically (Also after reinstalling the game via a steam restore operation due to a need of reformatting, which yielded a reset system settings file for GGXRD). Also tested on another computer with an Asus R7 250X 1GB which performs exactly like the HD 7770 recommended at the store page & it does run like butter on it. Also seems to perform fine on a HD 6850, but there appears to be problems still with some systems, especially laptops for some reason.

To continue, I now get a smooth 60fps across all circumstances in an extended hours of play & the fight pacing is so fast it's like a different game at all. But of course, that's the GG we all knew & love. Thank you Arksys. With this, I wholeheartedly turn the direction of my thumb for this game.

Where to start, okay. Graphics. I'm never for one to care much about it but this game is glorious. 3D which are made to imitate handdrawn drawings can usually still appear 3D, but this game is a game changer in that field. For most of the time you'll be playing this, I bet your ♥♥♥ your mind would think you're playing a 2D fighting game though that's not the case. It doesn't only look like one, but is animated like one too! The devs sure knows how 2D animation techniques works & implemented it flawlessly with the 3D models (suffice to say, that's a damn hard feat).

Next comes the rule book. Basically, the tutorial. Older GG fans know the stuff, but even then this is the first time that there's an actual tutorial explaining what are stuffs like Roman Cancel, Gattling Combination & Dead Angle, their mechanicsm & how to pull them off & in what situation. There is also a challenge mode which is basically where you learn combos & what probable combo chains you can create with them. This also gives newcomers an opportunity to edge up to veteran GG players quicker.

The fighting in GG is also known to be very fast, as in this one & perhaps the fastest in the genre of fighting games, yet it can also get very technical & requires precise input if you're really thinking of beating people. As hardcore as it is, GG is also surprisingly easy to get into. Any beginner can pick it up & could play it pretty well after sometime. Yet it's of those kind which is hard to master. Real mean gattling combos can get very tricky to pull off but the payoff is tremendous as you could juggle or pin down your opponent given they're clueless on how to get out of your mean pushes, but of course- if your opponent knows what he's doing, he can also save himself in many different way, so no unfair edge there.

Characters are also very diversified in terms of gameplay. Characters range from melee to ranged attackers to other weird shenanigans & none plays the same. The only downside to this however it'd take a really long time if you want to master them all as GG is the kind of game where it pays to main a character of your own choosing & play using him/her almost all the time. So take your pick & train hard. And if you play with too many too much, others will surpass you in any given character.

I'd rant longer. But I need to go to sleep but including this & what everyone's saying, it's a great game, simply put. Some of us are luck to not/no longer face bugs with the game, but hopefully continued support is provided & they can fix the problem.

reviewText:
Pretty sure every review that isn't oggling Ram has said most of what needs to be said.

Online is smooth and functional. Good luck finding Ranked matches, however. Most play will be in the Player Lobbies. Fortunately, as of the first month, there's usually a good number of lobbies and players with a range in skill, so it's easy to have fun getting your ♥♥♥ kicked and watching others follow your example. If you've got friends to play with, or want to engage in a great fighter online, then this a pretty gold example in a world where Netherealm servers are still a thing.

The tutorial and challenge modes are some of the best in the genre, easing in new players and vets alike to the system mechanics and basic fundementals before you ever have to tackle a real match. You can spend hours in training without even realizing it. The combat is streamlined compared to past entries, but for the better in most cases (YRCs never needed to be as stupid tight to pull off for how integral they are to Guilty Gear's combat).

Single player is a mixed bag outside of learning. Story is eh, but like the gameplay, does a good job of explaining everything to newcomers to the series, wraps up quickly enough and offers plenty to those willing to sink their teeth into it. Arcade is your simple 8 AI fights wrapping up with a rival and final boss. M.O.M mode is an incredible grind with RPG elements attached to the fighter experience, and that's really all that's left.

These modes might be more enjoyable if the AI were any bit competant but unfortunately they're pushovers. Even on the hardest difficulty setting they rarely play like any decent player, lacking any pressure or severe combos to punish players, and they give no indication as to how the respective character is meant to be played. This is crucial, because now a player not only needs to play against real players to test how valid their practice is, but to also learn matchups outside of the tiny bit the challenge modes cover. The AI is very bland by comparison to the great example SFV has set in place (Even if that is a much simpler game).

Also, as is usual of Aksys, this version of the game will soon be outdated in a few months thanks to their God awful PC Release schedules, and the same will be said of Blazblue CPE once that releases 2 years after the first iteration came to consoles.
If you own a PS3/4, wait for Revelator. If you only game on PC, this is the most accessible, up to date Guilty Gear available. If you've ever wanted to pick up on the series, start here and support more fighting games for PC.

While the Online mode has slightly less features (but nothing compromising) what I like that the PC is actually faster in terms of input lag (only 1 frame of input lag compared to the 4 of the PS4 version). Now this does not make the PC versione Arcade Perfect, HOWEVER it is absolutely a good thing if you plan to play this game online as the game being faster will make the online matches feel like the offline coin-op version of the game.\n\nUnless you are blessed with an active local scene or a group of friends that you can play with offline (for which I would recommend sticking to the PS4 version in that case), if you spend the majority of the time playing online then the PC version absolutely takes the cake.

reviewText: LOVE IT!!! Been a fan of the Guilty Gear series for a LONG TIME, and this one does not fail to deliver. Responds much better on PC than I hoped and actually fair enough for newcomers to pick up. If you haven't kept up with the series, you'll be fairly lost trying to get into the story. My only other complaint is the new art direction they went with in this one. A bit too cartoony compared to the others. Other than that, if you're a fan of the series you won't be disappointed. The story is FAR more fleshed out than in previous installments and leaves you with a good understanding of events that are taking place, if you've been a dedicated follower of the franchise. Absolutly worth a buy
